comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Magnificent things ... unfortunately like so many steam locomotives entering service in the 1950s the AD60-class's days were numbered by the increasing adoption of diesel locomotives by the NSWGR.

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] Aha, so [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] were right about it not being Lapstone-Glenbrook. So is it, in fact a trial run between Enfield-Hornsby-Broadmeadow? 

AB

comment.author: 35603348@N03
comment._content: The newspaper article is dated 2 August 1952 while this scene above is said to be three months later on 21 November. The photo, which has been published in at least one publication, was taken from the then highway overbridge above Emu Plains at the foot of the Blue Mountains. There is another view of this same train further along its journey at Valley Heights: www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4740534200/in/pho... It is also worth adding that the photo location is actually between Emu Plains and Glenbrook (or Lapstone although this latter station was not opened until 1964, at least 6 years after the railway's overhead electric wires reached Lithgow).

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/highplains68] Thanks for that interesting info; it also clears up some of the confusion! Emu Plains-Lapstone/Glenbrook would make more sense than Lapstone-Glenbrook. I'll pass this info along.

AB

comment.author: 15264656@N02
comment._content: It's certainly on the Emu Plains side, electrification didn't go through until 1956 I think so this location would have been clear of that when this photo was taken giving it a nice clean look. It is a bit hard to tell, could easily be mistaken for the north.

comment._content: That was the one mentioned in the newspaper article that went to Broadmeadow. Great shot!
